name: Ayesha
comment info:
Young women reach out to parents more overall as compared to young men. While only less than or about 25% of men and young women visit their parents in person at least once a day or a few times a week, more accesible ways of connection like Texts and calls show an even greater divide between the interaction of young men and women with their parents. 

I wonder if tradititional gender stereotypes affects how often a young person will reach out to their parents. Young men are typicall societally encouraged to be more independent and not ask for help as often, while women are expected to lead more domestic, family-centric lives. Does this phenomena have even deeper roots, such as biological instincts unique to each gender?

I have a very close relationship to my parents as I am the only child and only daughter. A lot of my family friends are adults who only have boys, and I am their “honorary daughter”. It’s frequently mentioned how much more I reach out to them, and that “parenting a girl is very different.”  
BY: AYESHA FROM FOSSIL HILL

name: Moderator Erica
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  “Are Young Men Ghosting Their Parents?” by Tatum of Andover High School in Mass.; "Parents and Children: How Connected Are They Really?" by Caroline of Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Morristown, N.J.; "Family Connections in the Digital Age" by Alea of Calif.; and three headlines from California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo – "Staying in Touch: Why Do Young Women Seem to Do It More Frequently?" by Miles, "Staying Connected: Young Women Lead in Family Communication" by Hailey and "Screen Age: How Electronics Have Impacted Parental Communication" by Aaron. 

 

Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article that included this graph, a summary of the article, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graph and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graphs and where you can find them in the graphs.

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This graph depicts the difference between young men and women and how likely they are to communicate with their parents daily. Womenare more likely than men to reach out to their parents at least once a day. However, it is mainly digital with just under 75% responding that they text and over 50% saying that they call their parents. Only about 25% of young women responded that they visit their parents on a daily or weekly basis. On the other hand, young men are far less likely to have active communication with their parents. About 50% text, between 25%-50% call, and less than 25% see their parents frequently. I wonder why the percentage of seeing parents regularly is so low. I understand that this poll was asked by 18-34-year-olds who live with either one or no parents, but I feel like this statistic is so low. I wonder how these statistics have changed over time. With the new age of social media and technology, has there been a significant increase in young people who can communicate with their parents daily? This relates to my community because as a teenager, communication is key with my parents and most of my friend's parents. If we do not answer them right away or frequently check in, parents nowadays are prone or getting anxious and hysterical. I wonder in the upcoming generation if these numbers will spike because of the constant communication needed between child and parent. 

“Call Your Mom! Young People And Their Lackluster Interest In Talking To Their Parents.”

name: Emma AOSE
comment info:
This graph shows the percentages of young people who say they reach out to their parents at least once a day or a few times a week. The data is from an online survey of 1,495 young adults ages 18 to 34. I notice that 75% of young women send texts to their parents at least once a day or a few times a week and only 50% of young men do that. I notice how young women send texts, phone or video-chat, and visit their parents in person at a higher rate than young men do. Why is this the case? Could it be because women are more family-oriented? Visiting in person is rated the lowest way to communicate or reach out to parents. Have social media and technology ruined genuine face-to-face conversations? I wonder if it's because the 18-34 age group lives away from home, in-person visits are unattainable. This affects me and my community because I have two older sisters, one who lives away from home and one who is in college and they communicate with my parents over texts and phone calls as it is easier.

name: Lauren
comment info: From first glance, it can be noted that it is more common for young women to communicate with their parents throughout the week. The statistics for all three categories for women combine to over 100%, suggesting that many young women not only frequently communicate with, but utilize several different methods, to talk to their parents. This is much higher compared to men, where the sum of all 3 categories barely reaches 100%, meaning that young men do not as regularly communicate with their parents. This may be because, according to societal standards, women are raised to be more mindful of their family and are meant to be more sensitive to the physical and emotional needs of those around them. Men, on the other hand, are raised according to the social conception of masculinity to become independent and less openly emotional or communicative in their relationships, meaning that young adult men will be less likely to maintain a close relationship with their parents.

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: However, I am curious what this means when looking at the visible disparity between men and women in long-distance communication, compared to personal visits where they are almost the same. If young women overall maintain a stronger belief in frequent communication with family than men, does this statistic mean that young women overall are more likely to live away from their parents than young men? If this is true, could this be caused by the comparative prevalence of higher education among the young women’s demographic, leading more women to move away from home, or perhaps the tendency of women to give more in a relationship or marriage, thus leading them to move further from home?

replies.name: L
replies.comment info: This relates to my community because I am from an East Asian country, which by nature has a strongly family-oriented culture, but attend a Western international school with the goal of sending students to live successful adult lives in America. These two conflicting norms of individuality, the goal where students are encouraged to cultivate individual strengths to become successful, versus its collectivist reasoning, where students are expected to become successful to support their parents, makes me interested in how this idea will affect me and my fellow classmates. I maintain a close relationship with my parents, but some of my peers have strained relationships due to academic pressures enforced by family, which along with gender may affect how often we as a group communicate with our own parents in the future.

name: Gabby
comment info:
What do you notice?
Young women tend to reach out to a parent more, in texting, calling, and visiting in person
The difference between young women and young men reaching out is similar for texting and calling, but the difference is much smaller for visiting (which requires a larger time and resource commitment). 

What do you wonder?
- Girls are socialized to be more family-oriented and social. Is that a cause of the “gap” between young men and young women reaching out?
- What do these gaps look like in various types of parents? (e.g. single mom, single dad, two moms, two dads) 
- What are the percentages of young people who reach out to immigrant parents vs. native-born parents? 
(Young people with immigrant parents may reach out not only for social purposes but for practical purposes such as helping with taxes and bills written in English.
Non-Western cultures tend to be more family and community-oriented than the more individualistic Western cultures)

How does this relate to you and your community?
My dad helps my grandparents with their healthcare, taxes, and bills because they don’t know English well. He has been doing this since he was a kid when their family immigrated to America. 
I have a very healthy relationship with my parents; I text them almost every day and call them weekly. Some people I know who have weirder dynamics with their parents reach out much less. 

Headline:
Gender Disparities In Young Adult Child Communication With Parents

name: Emma
comment info: The graph highlights a clear divide in communication frequency between young men and women with their parents. Across visits, texts, and calls/video chats, young women consistently reach out more frequently, with digital communication showing the largest gender gap, nearly 25% higher for women. This prompts questions about societal expectations and cultural influences shaping these patterns. Furthermore, the data suggests that in-person visits, while still less frequent overall, show a more modest discrepancy between genders. This raises questions about the significance placed on face-to-face interaction versus digital communication in parent-child relationships. Why do these gender differences manifest more prominently in virtual interactions? Reflecting on my own experience and community, I see the representation of young women, like myself, maintaining regular contact with parents, primarily through digital means due to distance. This underscores the importance of nurturing relationships beyond physical proximity, while also highlighting the need to address gender-based communication barriers within our community. A catchy headline is "Dialing Differences: Exploring Gender Disparities in Parental Connection".

name: Daniel Tsemekhman
comment info:
This graph provides fascinating insights into the communication habits of young adults aged 18-34 who live independently from their parents. The data highlights notable differences between genders in their preferred methods of maintaining regular contact.
Among young women, texting emerges as the dominant mode of communication, with 100% reaching out to a parent via text at least once a day or a few times per week. In comparison, only around 75% of young men exhibit the same texting frequency. Young men show a higher inclination towards phone or video chats, with approximately 75% using these methods regularly, as opposed to only about 50% of young women.
Interestingly, despite the prevalence of digital communication, a significant proportion of both genders, roughly 25%, still prioritize in-person visits with parents at least once a day or a few times weekly. This underscores the persistent value placed on face-to-face interaction in fostering close family ties. 
The data presents a nuanced picture of a generation navigating independence while striving to maintain strong parental connections. 

An interesting title may be: The Talk: Do Young Men or Women Talk More with Their Parents

name: Kaatje Matthews
comment info:
I notice how much higher the percentage of young women who reach out to their parents is than the percentage of young men who reach out to their parents. For texts and phone or video chats, this difference is really large, over a 20 percentage point difference. However, visits in person have a smaller difference between men and women, but women still have a higher percentage in this category by about 5 percentage points.

I wonder why this phenomenon occurs. What is the reason much less young men reach out to their parents than young women? What factors into this? Is it due to the difference between how girls and boys are raised and socialized?

This is related to me and my community since I, along with nearly everyone I am surrounded with on a regular basis, am in the age range this graphic examines. The way my relationship with my own parents is changing as I no longer live with them is interesting to me and I have become more aware of how much I talk to my parents, so having an idea of what types of communication are common amongst my age range is interesting to keep in mind.

Title: “How Adulthood Changes Communication in Parent-Child Relationships. ”

name: Karla Perez
comment info:
I've noticed that, generally speaking, women are more prone than males to communicate with their parents many times a week. It's also apparent to me that the majority of youth would rather text or contact their parents than see them.

How Do You Get in Touch With Your Parents?

name: Ashlyn Phillips
comment info:
First looking at the graphic, I noticed that for each form of communication, young women seemed to take the lead over young men in how often they reach out to their parents, whether through text, phone or in person. For instance, young women seem to send texts or talk on the phone with their parents 25% more frequently than young men. It appears that young women and young men are most similar in how often they visit their parents in person, with only about a 5% difference in frequency. Also, texting seems to be the most frequent form of communication for both young women and men. 
Something I wonder about this graphic is why women tend to reach out more to their parents.  On top of that, I also wonder which parent they tend to reach out to more overall. For instance, I call my mom practically every day to keep her updated on my college life and then she'll just fill in my dad. However, this probably varies from person to person, and it would be interesting to see.
This relates to me as a person because out of my brother and I, I tend to reach out more to my parents. This could be because I'm the second child and therefore rely on my parents more for some things, but I also believe it does have something to do with me being a young woman versus my brother being a young man. Between the two of us, we accurately represent these statistics and that tends to go for a lot of boy/girl sibling relationships.
"Communication Trends: How Youth Stay Connected with Parents Across Genders"

name: Matt Ferreira
comment info:
I notice that 50% of males say that they reach out to their parents through text at least once a week, while it’s around 70% for females. For phone calls, 30% of males do so at least once a week, and 55% of females do so. Even less percentages visit their parents once a week, with about 20% of males and 25% of females doing so.

Headline:
"Keeping Ties Strong: Gender Trends in Weekly Parental Contact Across Communication Channels"

name: Connor
comment info: I notice from this graph that the percentage of women who stay in touch with their families at least once a week is greater than the percentage of men across all mediums. Texting has the highest percentage of both men and women who reach out to a parent at least once a week, and visiting in person is the least popular for both men and women. The in-person visit category has the smallest difference in percentage between women and men, with women only having about a 5% greater percentage than men. name: Donya
comment info: Something that I noticed that’s pretty interesting to me (yet not very surprising!) is that young women tend to reach out to their parents more often than the young men in all three categories. Additionally, I’m surprised to see how often young men and women who do not live with at least one parent visit their parent(s) in person. I was actually expecting to see lower percentages for this category. I wonder how this data would change if the age range wasn’t so wide. For example, young men and women could be categorized as 18-22 instead of 18-34 (i.e. college aged people). I feel like this result in higher percentages for sending texts/phone calls and less visits in person as most young people in college are far away from home. This graph is really intriguing to me! I’m currently a third-year in college and tend to call my parents a lot. Luckily, I’m close enough to home that I can visit pretty frequently though. I think other college students in my community would find this graph interesting as well. I wonder how much other students’ opinions of this graph deviate from mine. Catchy headline: “Texts, Calls, Visits: How Today's Youth Communicate with Their Parents”.

name: Alex Tran
comment info: I noticed that the graph standardizes the scale of responses by using percentages instead of simply counting the number of responses. This allows for comparison between men and women, which I appreciate since it makes the graph more digestible for non-statisticians. I also noticed the ordering of the three methods of reaching out to convey the most common ways these young adults reach out to their parents. One thing I wonder is why women reach out to their parents at higher rates and how this potentially reflects the relationship that parents have with their female children versus their male children. I also wonder how we could incorporate other questions regarding communication with a parent into the survey as well, such as how qualitative the children believe their communication with their parent is. This relates to me as a college student because I struggle with making time to contact my parents (not on purpose) so I feel as though I cannot have the most interesting conversations with them, but I do believe it is nice to check in with them when I can. Furthermore, since I am away at college, I wonder how many of these survey respondents are college students and how that may affect how often they reach out to their parents as well. A catchy headline is “Parents Back Home: Are You Staying In Touch?”

name: Sophia Freije
comment info:
Right away I noticed that the percentage of young women who reach out to a parent a few times a week is higher than the percentage of men for all types of interactions. Specifically, this gap is largest for sending texts and calling on the phone. Meanwhile, the difference for in-person visits is much smaller (about 5 percentage points). Both genders are more likely to communicate via text compared to any other method.
I wonder why more women as opposed to men are willing to reach out to their parents. Is it because girls tend to form stronger bonds with their parents? Personally, I text or call my parents close to every day just to briefly check in with them, so this is the case for me. Other college students who also no longer see their parents daily, might not communicate as frequently because they are busy with their classes or work. Furthermore, everyone has a different relationship with their parents, so constant communication might be a low priority for some. I would name this graph “Leaving the Nest Does not Need to Mean Losing Touch”.

One last note is I wonder if the age range was reduced from 18-34 to instead be only individuals in college or even only individuals in their twenties would these percentages change? It might be interesting to see how when we look into smaller age ranges that encompass specific stages of people's lives, how people's interactions with their parents change.

name: Dechen Drongpa

name: Alexis Gywnn Hegarty

name: Isabelle
comment info:
The graph shows the percentage of young adults aged 18 to 34 who reach out to a parent at least once a day or a few times a week. It breaks down the communication methods into sending texts, phone or video-chat, and visiting in person. I noticed that while young women appear to reach out to their families at a higher rate than young men do, regardless of modality, that texting is the most common/ popular means of keeping in touch, as it has the highest percentages in either gender. 
Visiting in person shows the lowest gap between genders,  but is still less popular than other modalities.
I wonder how the way that female and male children are socialized impacts the way and the frequency with which they stay in parents-- are girls more prone to keeping in touch because they spent more time with parents, or because they feel it is expected? Of the participants that has high rates of contact, how many of them were eldest or only children? 
This resonates with me as my mom and I text nearly every day. Video and phone calls are harder to line up with different schedules, and in-person visits are the hardest-- we see each other a handful of times each year. Based on this, I'm inclined to think that schedule/ convenience has a decent weight behind the rates observed in this graph.
I think a good headline could be, "Texts and Calls: The New Bridge Between Today's Young Adults and Their Parents"

name: Daniel Magelky
comment info: One thing that I notice in the visualization is that young women, at least the ones included in the survey, tend to be in contact with at least one parent more than the young men included in the survey. This could be due to traditional societal roles, where men are seen to have to not feel emotions and having to be independent at a younger age than women. That if they are in contact with their parents more, they may think they are seen as weak, even though that is not true. I also notice that visiting in person is the lowest for both young men and women, which is most likely due to them moving away for jobs and/or college and they are unable to visit as much. One thing I wonder is how these responses would change by age. The survey questions asked those 18 to 34, a 16  year difference, which is a pretty big considering that it takes roughly 13 years between kindergarten and end of high school. Would the older ones be more or less likely than the younger ones to be in contact with a parent? Also, how does where the respondent go to school or do for work affect their contact status. This graph makes me want to be in contact with my parents more. I am very fortunate to have a good relationship with both parents, one where I could text or call them easily. I do stay in contact with them, but not as often as I think I should. Even a quick 10-minute conversation would be good. A catchy headline could be, "Parental Guidance – How Young Men and Women Differ in Contact with Parents."

The chosen colors create a clear contrast, enabling the audience to easily discern differences between the sexes. Additionally, I observe that the study's age range is confined to individuals aged between 18 and 34, which is likely to have influenced the outcomes presented in the graphic.


I wonder why women between 18 and 34 tend to reach out to their parents more than men of that age. One aspect that I believe may be worth considering is the evolving role of women in society. Over the past century, there has been significant progress in women's rights and opportunities. In this context, maintaining strong ties with parents can provide a sense of stability, guidance, and emotional support amid life's challenges and transitions.


This study is particularly relevant to my community at Cal Poly because many of my peers fall within the age range under investigation and meet the criteria for participation. By delving into this data, we can gain insights that might reshape our perspectives and behaviors concerning communication with our parents. For instance, members of our community, particularly men, might reconsider their communication habits after reviewing this data and opt to initiate more frequent contact with their parents.

Headline: A Battle of the Sexes
